Welcome to the beaches of Troy, where the weather is warm and Agamemnon prepares to take Troy for himself.
Agamemnon's forces, with your help, first besieged, then took the city of Troy. From within this fallen city's own walls, Agamemnon plots to shore up control of the surrounding region...

Argos is a close neighbor of Mycenae, and the two cities enjoy regular trade. In fact, they control a very lucrative port area along the coastline. \n \nBut recently, the mysterious Sea People have emerged there as a threat.

The Island of Crete is under attack from hordes of invading Lelegan Mercenaries, and King Minos has sent out a call for help to all of his embassies in the known world! Defend the island's sacred wonders and, if successful, be rewarded by King Minos.

Hail and well met, traveler! I am Marcus Pollux, proud owner of this fine establishment. 
 
Within these walls you will find some of the finest offerings, obtained on my frequent travels across this flat earth. Check back frequently, for I will always be adding new items.
 
Oh, and if you buy something, I'll deliver it to you outside the store. Security, know what I mean?

Villagers can gather Food, which is needed to train units. Select a Villager and right-click a source of Food to start gathering.
Villagers can gather Food from Berry Bushes...
... from fish that are near the shore...
To be successful on any quest, you need to gather resources as quickly as possible.
To increase efficiency, build Storehouses near gathering locations.
Instead of bringing resources all the way to your Town Center, Villagers use the Storehouse as a drop-off site.
You can also unlock technologies that increase Villager gathering rates.
Combat units are trained at military buildings like the Barracks.
To train combat units, select the military building and click the unit's icon in the Build menu.
Military units count against the population limit. To increase the population limit, use your Villagers to build Houses.
This is the cycle you'll repeat on most quests: produce Villagers to gather resources as quickly as possible to create an army large enough to defeat your opponent.
For example, you can build naval units like the Merchant Transport. It's used to move your units across bodies of water.
You can also build Farms. They generate an infinite amount of Food as long as they're being worked by Villagers.
Do you want to play against or with your friends? Then the first thing you need to do is form a party. There are multiple ways to do this.
Click on the Party icon to bring up a list of your LIVE friends. Select a friend who's online, and click Invite to send that friend an invitation.
Right-click a player's gamertag in the chat window to bring up a list of chat commands. Click Invite to send that player an invitation.
Finally, you can type /invite [gamertag], where [gamertag] is another online player's LIVE handle.
You have a special unit at your command on this quest, the Somatophylax.
To train this unit yourself, acquire Commander Matius for your Advisor Hall.
You have a special unit at your command on this quest, the Phalanx.
To train this unit yourself, acquire Commander Herculos for your Advisor Hall.
You have a special unit at your command on this quest, the Hetairoi.
To train this unit yourself, acquire Commander Jason for your Advisor Hall.
Welcome to Sparta, where we separate the weak from the strong. March upon your enemy and deliver victory. Prepare for glory!
Click to view. Right-click to remove.
Click to get more info on this Empire.
Earn Sparta Points to buy powerful items in Sparta.
You must retrieve your reward from the War Commander before you can start another match.
It takes a village - okay, lots and lots of villagers - to feed an empire, or something like that. Villagers gather resources and build structures. First up: gathering.
If you want to become the next great leader, you're going to have to order your units around. They love it. It makes them happy. Let me tell you how it's done.
Select a unit by clicking on it.
To order the unit to move or attack, right-click a valid destination or an enemy unit.
Press and drag a box around a group of units to select them.
Right-click an enemy to order all military units to attack the target.
All this talk of food is making me hungry. There's nothing better than wolf and berry gruel. Anyway, let's talk about speeding up the food gathering process.
It's time you starting breaking stuff. And by stuff, I mean heads. And by heads, I mean the heads of your enemies. To do that, you need an army.
You are now able to advance to Age II during a quest, and that gives you access to more powerful units and advanced technologies.
The times, they are a changing... that's what this one guy used to mumble all the time. With new times comes new ages. Let's talk about ages.
Somatomo... Somatomato... I have no idea how to pronounce these guys' name. But if you have a building that needs to be destroyed, these are the guys to do it.
You need some muscle? Herculos' guys will bring it. Funny, I thought a Phalanx was a formation, hmm....
There's nothing more exciting than seeing waves of cavalry like these Hetairoi stomp all over an enemy. I'm on a horse.
There comes a time when you need to commit to something. Like, say, a Crafting School. We're not talking paper-mâché here.
You pick a school at the Crafting Hall.
Once you pick a school, you can "learn" recipes for specific types of items that require that school.
Once a recipe is learned, you can craft equipment and consumables using acquired materials.
Think about the kinds of items you'd like to make before you choose a school.
To craft an item with one's own two hands and nine fingers is a direct link to our ancestors, and their ancestors, and that's pretty much it, right? What was I talking about again? Right, crafting.
You craft items at Crafting Halls. These structures are given to you based on your choice of school and are placed in your Capital City.
Each recipe has a list of "ingredients," or materials. There are multiple ways to acquire materials.
You can purchase Workshops that produce materials at a very slow rate until they reach capacity. You can clear their hoppers and add the materials to your inventory at any time.
There are also a number of "rare" or "epic" materials that can only be acquired through certain quests or as random loot drops. Good luck acquiring all of them!
Click to whisper. Right-click to remove.

Greece stands as a bastion of culture amid the powers warring for control of the Mediterranean. The Greeks are a classic military civilization: They are well-rounded and strong, but a bit slower to build.
 
Greece has a balanced navy, as well as classic historical infantry units, such as the powerful Hoplites, and big bruising cavalry units, such as the Hippikons.
 
Some of the civilization's more Elite units include the giant Siege Tower that shoots arrows at opposing forces known as Helepolis, which means "taker of cities."
 
Assume command of the Greeks as they navigate the tribulations of maintaining an empire in a region rife with conflict.

Egypt seeks to expand its borders through conquest while harried on all sides by kingdoms that seek the same. The Egyptians are cost-efficient and can ramp up quickly to destroy their enemies, but they are less durable in battle.
 
Egypt wields the sneaky Priest units, who not only heal but have the power to convert enemies, causing them to fight for the might of Egypt! But be sure to protect them, as they fall all too easily.
 
There are plenty of heavy-hitters in the Egyptian army, too, such as the War Elephants. These giant, lumbering Siege units not only lay waste to buildings but cause splash damage to nearby enemy forces.
 
Take control of the Egyptian forces and establish a dynasty throughout the region.

So let's say you pick up one of those booster packs, like Defense of Crete or Skirmish. You don't want any limits, am I right? Well, you're no longer limited. Not really, anyway.
Boosters grant you access to all units, even if you haven't unlocked them in the Tech Tree during the campaign.
You also have access to all of the ages, even if you haven't reached the required city level.
You do not, however, get access to all technologies. These still need to be unlocked through leveling up.
Experience earned from boosters can be used to level up, fully unlocking units and technologies and improving their rewards.
All units are unlocked and battle-ready at any level!

The Village of Sens is the home of the Senones tribe of northern Celtica. The people are commanded by the great warrior Brennos. The Senones are an honorable people who are always ready for a fight.
Vindelicia is the home of the Vindelici tribe. The Vindelici command a large amount of the Eastern Alps all the way to the Adriatic Sea. Drust currently guides the people.

Massalia is a coastal port town founded by the Greek, Protis, and his Celtic wife, Gyptis. Massalia is a bustling trade port, trading Celtic metal for Greek wine. Since it is a place of great wealth, Massalia is often under attack by pillaging Celtic tribes.

Tylis is a Celtic city-state founded by Comontorios. It is the staging point of the Celtic invasion of Greece. Tylis' presence in the region unnerves the Thracians and other nearby city-states, and many pay tribute to avoid conflict.

To list an item in the Marketplace, drag it to the highlighted area.

When listing items in the marketplace, you select your item, drag it to the Marketplace, set your price, click "List," and it's available for purchase to everyone on your realm.
 
There is a cost for listing your item; however, it's refunded when the item is sold. It isn't refunded if you de-list the item or goes unsold.
 
The Global Marketplace also takes a percentage cut of the sell price, because that's just how I do business.
 
If you sell an item, you can return to the Global Marketplace to pick up your coin.
 
Finally, anything left in the Marketplace for 30 days will be permanently removed.
 
If it's an item, it will deleted; if it's coin, you will lose it. If you're going away for a while, you might want to consider de-listing all of your Marketplace items.

It is good to see you. With your leadership, we will unite the tribes and become a civilization that is the envy of the world! 
 
We are mighty, and we must use that might to protect those who cannot protect themselves. A nearby tribe is currently under assault by Barbarians. 
 
Those uncultured brutes will destroy everything if left alone. Go and slaughter them all!

The Legion of Carthage is an alliance headed by Hannibal, the famous general of Carthage who crossed the Alps. The Legion focuses on the military aspects of the empire.

The Delian League is a confederacy of Greek states that meets at the island of Delos. Archimedes is a famed mathematician, inventor, and astronomer who guides the league towards victory through economy.

The Council of Imhotep is headed by the famed vizier Imhotep, a polymath skilled in architecture, engineering, and medicine. Those working alongside Imhotep wish to elevate their civilization through the use of technology and usher peace through religion.
Are you sure you want to leave your Alliance? \n \nRank and Alliance Points for current contests will be reset.
Hmm, this is a big decision. You're losing all of your current and historical Alliance points, your current Rank, and possibly the respect of all of your fellow Alliance members.
Alright, then. It's done. You're now a free agent, able to pick and choose a new Alliance. I hear they're all recruiting.
Are you sure you want to join the %s?

So you're ready to sign on the dotted line, right? Here are some things to consider:
 
 Your Alliance choice isn't just for this civilization; it's for all of your civilizations on this Realm.
 
Each Alliance has unique bonuses and quests. The Alliance quests require membership for both solo and co-op play, so make sure you pick the same Alliance as your friends.
 
You can change Alliances, but your Alliance Points and rank will be reset.
 
If you're cool with everything, join away! Otherwise, keep shopping.
Boom, it's done. I'd welcome you to your new Alliance, but I can't really play favorites. Head on over to your Alliance's home region and talk to the Alliance leader. Good luck.

Wanna deal a blow to the other Alliances without getting your hands too dirty? "Sabotage" their War Efforts with a percentage of the Alliance Points you earn, decreasing their War Effort totals.\n \nKeep in mind, any changes are not retroactive!
You need to be in %s to use this item.

Leader of the Legion of Carthage

Carthage was founded in northern Africa by the Phoenician Queen Elissa. The city's coastal location and artificial harbors make it a major player in Mediterranean trade. It is one of the largest cities in ancient times, and it is the base of power for the Carthaginian Empire. The Legion of Carthage is located here, and Hannibal supports all civilizations that believe that victory is best achieved through combat.

The Farafra Oasis is a remote location in northwest Egypt. The area is associated with Hathor, the goddess of fertility. The hot sulfur springs at Bir Setta relax weary bones, and the White Desert is home to strange and dynamic rock formations. This quiet place is the headquarters of the Council of Imhotep, where Imhotep himself guides civilizations to greatness through culture and religious focus.

Delos is an island in the middle of the Cyclades, and it is the sacred birthplace of Apollo and Artemis. Even though its land is not fertile, its religious importance gave it a wealth of resources. No one was allowed to be born or die on the island, making it a truly neutral location among the Greeks. Delos is the meeting ground and treasury of the Delian League, and Archimedes serves as mediator amongst the nations.

Command the masters of Mesopotamia!
 
Travel to the fertile plains between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers and take command of the mighty Babylonian Civilization. 
 
Head straight into battle at level 20 with unique units like the mighty Lancer Cavalry, with its Charge upgrade. Construct a Garden or Ziggurat to empower your troops and advance through the Ages. Garrison your units in your mobile Siege Tower and fire barrages of arrows at your enemy. 
 
Get immediate access to Rare and Epic gear, Advisors, and Ranked PvP; increase your Capital City warehouse storage; get more Workshops; and receive Coin when other players buy from your stores.
 
Perfect for PvPers and those who want to rush to the Alliance Wars.
Over 30 all-new quests for levels 20 and above
Travel to Media to reign in the Mad Median and his raiders!
Visit the new region of Babylon
An alternative to leveling in Argos

Looking for more quests? 
 
The Fertile Crescent Booster offers 30 all-new quests for level 20 cities and beyond.
 
Located in the fertile plain lands between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers and ruled by King Nebuchadnezzar II, Mesopotamia is often considered the cradle of civilization with its advanced irrigation systems and written laws known as Hammurabi's Code.
 
But a code of law is only effective if it can be enforced, and the Mad Median's raiders refuse to follow the rules. It's up to you to prove that the Mad Median and his raiders are not above Hammurabi's Code-or fist. You must protect the crown jewels:  Babylon and her queen.

Expand your Vault to up to 240 total slots with Empire Points!

Need more space? Find yourself constantly mailing items to your other civs? This is the feature you need. 
 
The Empire Vault is a shared Inventory for all of your civs on your current realm. 
 
It comes with 4 shared Inventory slots, and you can expand it to up to 240 slots with Empire Points.
Rename your city. This costs Empire Points.

Right-click items in your inventory to add them to your Empire Vault and access them on any other civilization on this realm. Right- or left-click Vault items to return them to your inventory.\n \nIf you need more space, click the Expand Vault button.

In this mode, you will be evenly matched against other players from across the globe based on your skill-based ranking.
 
Your gear is used for visuals only, you have access to all units and techs regardless of your level, and your results will be added to the global leaderboard.
 
Gather your party, select the match type, and click "Quick Match" to march upon your enemy and deliver victory. Prepare for glory!

In this mode, you will be matched against other players based on your level and your skill-based ranking. 
 
Your gear matters, as their stats are applied to your units. Advisors are also used, allowing customization of your civilization. There is no leaderboard.
 
Gather your party, select the match type, and click "Quick Match" to march upon your enemy and deliver victory. Prepare for glory!

In the ancient world, the most northern lands of Europe were a frontier inhabited by a wide variety of people including the Norse, the Teutons, the Celts, and other ancient Germanic tribes.\n \nClimate change due to a "Little Ice Age" forced the Norse people to move south to stay alive, causing later conflict, culture blending, and sharing of technologies.
Do not fail me in this.
Infantry can build factories and defensive structures
Flagship units: Throwing Axeman, Berserker, War Dog, Seer

Go on the offensive with the mighty Norse!
 
This civilization from the north excels at controlling the map and launching powerful attacks through their unique ability to construct Buildings with their Infantry.
 
Their aggressive play-style is further reinforced by their powerful scouting tools, including two Scouts and Seers that can summon Ravens to fly around the map and scout the enemy's base.
 
Head straight into battle at level 20 with other units like the Throwing Axemen, Berserker, and War Dog.

Athens is the largest Greek city and in many ways the cradle of Western culture due to its advances in art, science, and philosophy. It is also widely considered the birthplace of democracy. The iconic Parthenon watches over the city from atop the Acropolis.

Set's Light Spear of the Solstice

Rhakotis is an ancient city along the Egyptian coast. For generations, Egyptian Pharaohs fortified Rhakotis with armored Sentinels, who would patrol the Mediterranean to protect the lavish Egyptian treasures from foreign sailors, especially the plundering Greeks. The Sentinels set guard over Rhakotis, and even its citizens and neighboring herdsmen prevented the approach of outsiders.

We are a small community and we are all here to have fun. Wasting your opponent's time by hiding Town Centers in the corner of the map, not actively playing the match to win, or any similar activity that would needlessly prolong a match is greatly discouraged. \nThank you for helping us maintain a positive and fun environment for everyone playing the Ranked ladder.

Each player is allowed to have only one account. If it is determined by our moderator team that you are using multiple accounts, the mandatory minimum punishment is removal of all game items related to whatever multi accounting helped you achieve, and removal of all coin and empire points. \nThe maximum punishment if determined appropriate by our moderator team, is a permanent ban from the game.

Ranked PvP is a competitive environment for players who want to get placed on the leaderboards. It is not meant to be used as a custom games environment. If you want to play games with or against your friends, please use the Arena. We monitor account activity in Sparta very closely to ensure the best possible experience for our players.
I Have Been Banned By Mistake. What Do I Do?

If you feel like you received a ban by mistake, you may submit a Ban Appeal ticket in our forums and your account will be placed under review. \n \nVisit www.projectceleste.com/rules for more information.
How Do I Report A Player?

If you see someone breaking these rules, please send a report to one of our Moderators at our Discord server and we will have a look at your report as soon as possible. Don't forget to include a screenshot, if possible. \nThank you for helping us keep the community the best it can be!

Earn various rewards for each consecutive day of logging in!
 
The progress bar below shows your current reward track for this week. Your rewards will be determined by your highest level civilization, so it does not matter which civilization you're using to redeem the rewards. 
 
If you miss a day of logging in, you will still get the next reward on the progress bar.
 
So for example, if you log in on days 2, 3 and 5, you will get the rewards for days 1, 2 and 3.
 
The reward sets reset every week so make sure to log in as soon as you can!

Welcome to the PvP Combat Guide

Here you can find everything you need to get started with PvP combat in Age of Empires Online. 
 
Click on one of the icons on the left to get started. 
 
Click on the icon below to view information about Champion Mode, including Tech Trees, Unit Stats and active Ranked maps, alongside a link to join the PvP Discord where you can find additional learning resources and interact with other players to discuss strategies, find practice partners, and play games together! 
 
Glory to the brave, we will see you on the battlefield.

They don't! While playing Champion Mode PvP (the default PvP mode in Sparta and Arena) gear is used only for visuals and everyone has access to the same Units, Technologies and Stats, regardless of their level and everyone plays on equal grounds.

Nope! You get rewards for playing PvP matches regardless of winning or losing, so it doesn't matter if you don't win every game. Every game you play also counts towards your seasonal badge progress. You don't lose anything by losing your match, so don't worry!
In addition to Coin, Sparta Points and Empire Points, you also become eligible for End-of-Season rewards, Legendary Gear, special seasonal badges and more! Check the Rewards page for more details.

This guide will provide you with everything you need to get started. Once you are done reading, you can also visit our Forums, Discord and YouTube channels for additional learning resources. Don't be afraid to ask any questions you might have. We have an awesome community!

Constantly train Villagers until you have 70-90 of them. The only time your Town Center should not be training Villagers is when you are aging up or researching something in it. If you follow this simple yet critically important rule, you will quickly see improved results in your matches.

Idle Villagers are nothing but a detriment to your economy. Constantly pay attention to the Idle Villager notification and make sure to assign a Hotkey for it (Default Hotkey: V) so you’re always ready to task your idle Villagers to get to work and not stand idle. Idle Villagers are useless Villagers!

Try and keep all of your resources spent at all times. The only time you should stop spending resources is for when you are saving up to advance to the next Age or to research an expensive upgrade. If you are starting to stockpile on a certain resource, don't hesitate to move your Villagers from one resource type to another!

Constantly train Military Units. The only time when you should consider stopping Military Unit production is when you are saving up resource to research an expensive Upgrade, or to build an expensive Building, such as a Town Center, or a Fortress.

Many new players don't make enough Buildings. Having additional Military production Buildings allows you to reinforce much faster so that you can overwhelm your opponent and go for a victory. Have extra Wood stockpiled? Make some more Military Buildings!

Upgrades improve your Villagers' efficiency, your Military Units' combat effectiveness and benefit your civilization in various ways. Armory Upgrades are particularly important, as they make your Units much more cost-effective and pop-effective, resulting in a much higher quality army. Research them as soon as possible!

Hotkeys allow you to perform actions much, much faster than you would otherwise be able to. By default, Unit Production Hotkeys are based on an ASDF layout on your keyboard. You can easily remember this layout and train Units by pressing the corresponding Hotkey for them, rather than clicking on their icons. 
 
Another group of Hotkeys are "Find Unit Hotkeys" which allow you to quickly select a Unit and Building, regardless of where it is on the map. You can utilize this type of Hotkey in various situations such as when you want to find your Scout to do more Scouting, or perhaps when you want to select a Storehouse to quickly research an economy upgrade without looking for a Storehouse on the map and clicking on it. 
 
There are many different and useful Hotkeys in the Hotkeys section of the Options menu. Take your time and learn them. You won't regret it!

Control groups let you select Units or Buildings that currently aren't on your screen and learning them will turn you into a much better player. 
 
You can create a new control group by selecting a Unit or Building, holding Ctrl and then pressing a number key. 
 
For example, Ctrl + 1 would assign control group 1 to any Unit or Building you have selected and you can simply press 1 to highlight it, wherever it is. 
 
If you want to add new Units or Buildings to your Control group, you can select them and hold Shift + 1 to add them to your existing Control group 1. 
 
Check the "Selection Group Hotkeys" section of the Hotkeys menu to find out more about Control Group Hotkeys.

The mini-map is an excellent tool to keep an overview of what's going on in your match. You can see enemy Units moving towards your base and prepare your defenses accordingly, always being one step ahead of your opponent. \n \nYou can also keep an eye on different Resources on the map, both for yourself and your opponent.
The goal of this build is to have some Age I Military Units early on to either put some pressure or defend against the opponent's pressure.

Start by sending your first 3 Villagers to the nearby Trees. 
 
The next Villagers that are trained from your Town Center will go to the nearest Huntables and build a Storehouse there. 
 
Once you have 200 Wood (after spending 50 Wood to build your Hunt Storehouse) you can start building your Barracks. 
 
Gather 50 more Wood so you can afford a Storehouse next to your Woodline. 
 
The next Villagers from your Town Center will go to the Hunt to increase your Food income so you can afford making Villagers and Military Units. 
 
If you use this opening to be aggressive you can use your units to harass your opponent’s Hunt or Woodline. When harassing their Woodline keep constant attention to your Units so they don’t get hit by too many shots from your opponent's Town Center. 
 
Once you can sustain Villager and Military production, build a Storehouse next to your Stone Mine and start gathering Stone so you can build your second Town Center when you reach Age II.
This build will allow you to get ahead of your opponent by securing an economic advantage early on, but is susceptible to early aggression.

Start by sending your first 3 Villagers to your Hunt. 
 
Your fourth Villager (The first one you train) will build a Storehouse in your Woodline. 
 
Your fifth villager will go to your Hunt (4 total). 
 
Sixth and Seventh Villagers will go to your Woodline (3 total). 
 
Eighth Villager will build a Storehouse at your starting Stone Mine. 
 
Ninth and Tenth Villagers will also go to your Stone Mine (3 total). Eleventh villager will go to your Wood (4 on Wood total) and the Twelvth villager will go your Stone Mine (4 total). 
 
As soon as you have 200 Food and 200 Wood you can age up. Take 2 Villagers from your Hunt and send one to your Woodline (5 total) and another to your Stone Mine (5 total). As soon as you age up you should have around 300 Wood and 300 Stone and you can build your 2nd Town Center. 
 
Take your 5 Villagers off of your Stone Mine and build your 2nd Town Center.
 
While you are aging up, make sure to know where you are going to place it. It can be in a more defensive position, such as in range of your first Town Center, on your Woodline, Gold Mine or another resource. 
 
Alternatively if you know your opponent didn't make early Military Units you can build your 2nd Town Center a bit further away to secure some resources outside of your main base. 
 
This build will need small variations if you play the Babylonians, due to the need to make extra Ox Carts but the timings are roughly the same and you can adjust your build with a little practice. Practice makes perfect!
This build is more advanced than the previous two, and should be used only on maps with Water available. Use it only once you're comfortable with the previous builds.

In the Mountain Crossing map you can use your Dock as your first Wood Storehouse, placing it between to your Woodline and the lake behind you. You can build the dock with the fourth Villager, the initial three being on your closest Hunt. 
 
Based on what resource you need the most, you can assign the Villager who built the Dock to either gather from the Fish next to your Dock, or the Woodline next to it.
 
On other maps like Inland, Oasis or Treasure Island you can build a fast Dock after your Hunt and Wood storehouse. You send your initial 3 Villagers to your Hunt, the fourth one to build a Storehouse on the Woodline. 
 
The next Villagers that train of your Town Center will go to your Woodline. Once you have 100 Wood you can start sending a Villager to the shoreline, so once it gets there you have around 150 wood to build your dock. 
 
Some civilizations (such as the Babylonians) have docks that cost 200 wood, so send your Villager a bit later. 
 
Alternatively, you can build your dock off of one Storehouse, sending your fourth Villager to build the dock and gather Wood around your Hunt Storehouse or around your Town Center. 
 
Since Fishing Boats will provide you with a very high Food income, you can leave only 3 Villagers on your Hunt and send the rest of your Villagers to your Woodline. If your Dock gets attacked by your opponent, don't hesitate to use your Fishing Boats to repair it! They also have a Ranged Attack that can be used to buy time for you until you can train some Military Units of your own to defend against the incoming pressure. 
 
When using this build, pay attention to what your opponent is doing by Scouting them. If they are also going for a greedy strategy, you can start gathering Stone and make a Town Center in addition to your Dock, giving you lots of extra resources. But if your opponent is opting for a more aggressive strategy, be careful not to get overrun by the opponent's Military aggression before you have anything to defend with.
2. Use your Dock as a dropoff

Every civilization has access to their Barracks in Age I. By making a Barracks early on, not only do you enable yourself to defend against early aggression from your opponent, but also to move out with your own troops and put pressure on your opponent instead.

Loom increases your Villagers' survivability by a substantial amount, so if your opponent is being very aggressive with their units in Age I, consider researching this Upgrade early on so you have more time to react and escape with your Villagers. Better safe than sorry!

Scouts are excellent at delaying your opponent's incoming Units. Keep a close eye to your opponent's Barracks and as soon as you see them sending Units towards your base, start attacking them with your Scout.

If you are being overwhelmed by your opponent's Units, quickly move your Villagers away from your hunts and start gathering from the Berry Bushes next to your Town Center instead. 
 
Even though Berries are slower than Hunts, it's better to gather from Berries safely than to lose your Villagers. 
 
Don't forget to research Picker's Gloves if you do so!

Generally speaking, there are 3 main Military Unit types that you will most commonly deal with when playing PvP Matches - Infantry, Ranged and Cavalry. 
 
In almost every case, the counter system works this way: 
 
Infantry beat Cavalry 
 
Cavalry beat Ranged 
 
Ranged beat Infantry 
 
There are a few exceptions to this rule, but you can find out about each unit's specific role by hovering over its icon in the Unit Production tab (inside each Building). 
 
Making the proper Units against what your opponent has is the key to victory!

Attack Move is a command that you can give to your Unit by pressing the Attack Move Hotkey (Default Hotkey: A) and then left-clicking somewhere on the ground. The unit will move towards that destination, attacking the closest enemy Unit or Building that it encounters along the way. \n \nThis is most useful for Melee Units to ensure that they all attack the enemy and not stand idle at the back.

As explained in the previous tip, Attack Move commands Units to attack the nearest enemy Unit. 
 
When using Ranged units, this leads to all of your Units attacking the same target, resulting in massive overkill where your Ranged Units all attack one single enemy Unit, wasting most of their Damage until they are ready to fire their next volley. 
 
It's better to move your Ranged units and then use the Stop Command Hotkey (Default Hotkey: S) which will result in your Ranged units evenly spreading their fire.
 
So to quickly summarize: Attack Move your Melee Units. Stop Command your Ranged Units. (This also extends to Ranged Siege Units, not just Bowman Type units.)
1. Find all of the same Type

When you need to select every Unit of the same Type (such as all of your Spearmen) you can simply hold Ctrl and then left-click on one of those units. It will highlight every Unit of that Type on your screen. 
 
This is very useful for situations such as when you want to move your Spearmen to defend against the flanking Cavalry of your opponent, or when you want to use your own Cavalry to flank the enemy backline. 
 
Another way of selecting every Unit of the same Type is using the "Find all of the Selected Unit" Hotkey (inside the Find Unit Hotkeys section), but beware that this will select every Unit (or Building) of the same type in the match, regardless of where they are, unlike the Ctrl-Click method which only selects the ones on your screen.

Enabling this option inside the "Camera and Chat" section of the Options menu will allow you to select only Military Units when dragging a box around them. 
 
This is particularly useful for moving your Military Units around without taking your Villagers off of the resource they were gathering. 
 
If you enable this option, you can hold Alt and then drag around your Units to include Villagers (and other non-Military Units, where applicable) in your selection.

Harassing your opponent's economy is pivotal in securing yourself an advantage and winning the match. 
 
Send some of your faster Units to attack the enemy Villagers. Cavalry and faster Infantry Units are great choices for this. 
 
In return, you should have some of your own Units next to your Villagers in order to be prepared to defend against your opponent's raids.

Against Units that have Splash (area-of-effect) Damage such as Siege Units or Fortresses, it is very important to make sure that your Units are not clumped up together in a small area. 
 
Quickly select a group of your Units and move them away from the center of the Damage Area, then select another group and move them in another direction to minimize the Damage taken. 
 
Similarly, when using Units that have Splash Damage, try and target groups of enemy Units to get the most out of your Splash Damage Unit.

Units that stand back in the army are generally high Damage but low Health units. This is particularly true for Bowman Type Units. \n \nSend your Anti-Ranged Units (such as your Cavalry) to move around the backline and flank them, quickly killing them and relieving a lot of pressure from your own front line.

Particularly useful in the early game where Unit counts are low and every single Unit counts. 
 
Pay attention to your Units' Health Bars (located above them) and pull them back from the fight right before they die. 
 
If your opponent doesn't pay attention, their Units will start attacking your other Units, allowing you to get out of the fight with your injured Unit.

Storehouse Upgrades are one of the most important aspects of economy management. Make sure you get your Upgrades as soon as you can. If you are gathering from Berries, make sure to research Picker's Gloves.

Your Villagers move farther into the treeline over time. This will result in lots of gathering time lost when walking from Trees to Storehouses. Constantly replace your Wood Storehouses to ensure efficient Wood gathering.

Huntable animals and Berry Bushes are both great Food sources. However, Huntables gather much faster than Berries, therefore you should try and gather from them before moving over to Berries. \n \nBe careful, however, that while Huntables are a faster source of Food, they also deplete faster than Berries and are usually more exposed than them.

When building a Storehouse next to Gold and Stone deposits, make sure to leave a gap between them and the Storehouse so your Villagers can fit in and have efficient gathering. Taking that one extra second to carefully place your Storehouse can been a huge difference in your income in the long run!

Once you reach your maximum population capacity, you will be unable to queue up any additional Units. This can be devastating especially in the early game. One easy way of not getting House blocked is having 1 Villager constantly building one House after another.

It is important to have a balanced economy. Pay attention to what army composition you are going for and then distribute your Villagers based on that. 
 
Going for an Infantry-heavy army? You will need more Villagers on Food than you normally would. 
 
Going for mainly Ranged Units? Send more Villagers to Wood. You can see the number of Villagers on each resource on the bottom right corner of each resource's icon in the resource bar at the top of the screen (As shown in the picture). You can also click on those icons to move your camera to a group of that resource's gatherers. 
 
A sign of a good player is to know when to change their Villager distribution to match their Unit composition's required resources. Don't be afraid to move Villagers around!
Storehouses can be used as a resource dropoff for every resource Type. Take advantage of this and build Storehouses in places where you can gather from more than one resource Type at a time!

While Gold Deposits are the primary source of Gold for most of the game, they will eventually deplete and then your only source of Gold would be to use Caravans. Think ahead and plan a Market route for yourself. 
 
Send one or two Villagers to build a Market as far away from your Town Center as possible. The longer the travel distance between your Market and your Town Center, the more Gold your Caravans will bring in. 
 
Be careful, however, that the longer your Market route is, the more susceptible it is to being attacked from your opponent, so try to find a balance between distance and safety. 
 
Once you are done building your Market, you can use the same Villagers to build Walls (and Guard Towers) next to your market to help defend it.

Fishing is another source of Food that you can utilize. They are by far the best way of gathering Food, particularly in the early game where your Dock can act as an extra Economic Unit prodcution facility, while your Town Center trains Villagers to be sent to gather from other resources. But it is also the riskiest source of Food. If your opponent manages to kill your Fishing Boats or destroy your Dock, then you will be stranded for Food and your economy will suffer a major blow while you try to fix it. \n \nKeep an eye on your opponent's activity if you opt to go with a Dock. If they move out against you, be prepared to defend your Fishing Boats. Remember that Fishing Boats have a Ranged Attack and can repair (both your Dock and each other!) so use them to buy yourself some time while you send some land Military Units to aid your Dock's defense.

Huntables are one of the fastest sources of Food available. When the match starts, try and find your nearby Huntables and kill them with your scout (they don't decay!). You can then bring your Villagers and build a Storehouse next to them and start gathering Food. \n \nFor the most efficient gathering possible, try and spread your Villagers so that you have one on each Huntable animal.

Once you are done killing your Huntables, send your Scout towards your opponent's base. See where their resources are located, if they are gathering from Huntables or Berries, if they are making early Military Units, etc. \n \nKnowing what your opponent is doing is extremely important in making your next decisions. Keep on Scouting!

Keep an eye on your opponent's Stone deposit. If they are mining Stone, it is likely that they are going for an early 2nd Town Center. Knowing this can help you make a decision whether you want to respond with a Town Center of your own, or to try a more aggressive strategy. \n \nBe careful, though! If your opponent only has 1-2 Villagers on Stone, it may mean that they are going for an aggressive Tower Rush strategy! In that case, make sure to opt for a more defensive strategy and be prepared for a Tower Rush.

Watch Posts are very useful for getting vision on key parts of the map. Use your Scout to build them in strategic places (such as where your opponent might send a group of units to attack you, or a Gold Deposit that your opponent might start gathering from soon) so you're always one step ahead. \n \nIn case your Scout dies, you can still use your Villagers to build Watch Posts. Preparation is key!

Types of Items found in Treasure Chests
The main source of Treasure Chests are Quest Rewards.
You can find new Quests by talking to various Quest Givers in the game.
While playing Quests, you will encounter guarded camps that contain Treasure Chests.
The number and quality of Chests you get depends on how well guarded the camp is.

The majority of the items present in the game belong to the Classic Set. This Set contains every item that existed in the game prior to Project Celeste.
 
Advisors, Materials, Gear, Consumables, Blueprints and Crafting Recipes can all be found in the Classic Set. 
 
Once you reach level 40, you also have a chance of finding legendary items in level 40 Treasure Chests (this includes all level 40 Treasure Chests, not only legendary ones, although Legendary Treasure Chests have a much higher chance of dropping legendary items).

This Set contains newer items that were added in Project Celeste, and it is the Set that continues to receive new items. 
 
Available only after reaching level 40 (and also in Event Quests, regardless of level), Chests from this Set have every item from the Classic Set in them, with the newer items also included in their loot table. 
 
You can see which Quests have Treasure Chests from the Celeste Set by looking in the rewards section of Quest description. 
 
You can also search for Celeste items using the Search Tool on our website and searching for “celeste”. Click on the button below to open the Search Tool!

● Fishing Boats gather Fish 5x faster and carry 2x more. 
● Merchant Transports trade for 5x more Gold and carry 450 additional gold per trip (for a total of 750 Gold per trip).

Salutations! 
 
I'm King Minos, King of Crete, collector of Minotaur horns and owner of the biggest Maze in existence. 
 
Can't decide which civilization to pick? Click on one of the icons below to get a quick overview on each of them!

The Greeks are the generalist civilization of Age of Empires Online. \n \nTheir gameplay is very straightforward and rock-paper-scissor oriented, giving them a clear answer to anything thrown at them. They are a great first choice for any beginner.
Powerful Elephants and Strength in Numbers

The most notable difference between Egyptians and other civilizations is their age-up and empowerment mechanics. They are able to age up by building Temples instead of researching a technology in their Town Center. Each of those temples provide them with unique and powerful priests that can be used for economic, military and utility purposes. \n \nThey have access to powerful War Elephants and Elephant Archers in their Fortress and their barracks units are cheap and very quick to produce. Just when you thought you've won against the Egyptians, another stampede of powerful Elephants, Slingers, Axemen and Spearmen come swarming your way.
● Cheap, easy to replace Barracks Units
● Map Control in the early game
● Able to keep training Villagers while aging up
● Somewhat vulnerable in the very early game
● Expensive Elephants that are costly to replace

The Celts offer a unique gameplay experience unlike any other civilization by their incredibly strong Infantry Units and powerful Druids - who heal friendly units in battle and giving them a damage boost while doing so - and their ability to get temporary boosts through ritual animal sacrifices. \n \nEven though their Unit roster may have more holes in it than any other civilization, their brute force and frightening mobility makes for a potentially risky but very rewarding experience.
● Lack of powerful lategame Siege Units

The Persians use Toggle Techs, which are a unique mechanic that offer powerful bonuses while having a cost in return. Able to be toggled on and off at any moment's notice, they allow the Persians to adjust their stategy on the fly and adapt to any situation. \n \nCommand the powerful Persian Immortals, who possess both a Melee and a Ranged attack and can decimate any Infantry unit in their wake, or the mighty Asabaras, extremely versatile and well-rounded Cavalry units who join the fight as early as Age 2.
● Access to healing in the early game

The Romans bring a new aspect to Age of Empires Online - Officers. 
Officers are powerful, semi-heroic Units that greatly impact battles and increase the effectiveness of your other Units. Having Officers in your army can quickly make the difference between a decisive victory and a crushing defeat. 
 
The Romans Units are fairly well-rounded, like their Greek counterparts, but are also generally more expensive and even more bottle-necked by their Economy. Utilize Roman Engineers to greatly speed up Building construction while your Villagers spend more time gathering resources rather than constructing Buildings.

The Babylonians are unique in that they have access to the Ox Cart - a mobile storehouse that follows your Villagers around, eliminating the need to constantly replace storehouses, saving you lots of resources and greatly boosting your Economy. \n \nEven though the Babylonians have access to a Military on par with other civilizations, you will find yourself securing an advantage and winning the game when utilizing their incredibly powerful Economic upgrades and their Gardens, which reduce the training and research time of all Buildings while also granting you a trickle of Food.
● Cheap Wooden Walls (can be upgraded later)
● Sustained Fights and constantly trading Armies
● Ox Carts can be difficult to replace
● Expensive Gardens that are costly to replace

The Norse make an epic return from Age of Mythology. Many of the mechanics players remember from the Norse in Age of Mythology are back - such as being able to construct Military Buildings with your Infantry Units and always being on the offensive. 
 
The Norse also have access to War Dogs, fast, mobile Units that cost no population (but have a Build Limit) that can greatly slow down enemy Units, allowing your Army to catch up and send them to their demise. 
 
When playing the Norse, you will find that you will always be in control of the map. Use your map control wisely to secure yourself an advantage!
● Map Control in the early game
● Can construct Military Buildings with Infantry
● Lack of powerful lategame Siege Units
● Expensive Berserkers that are costly to replace
Complete The Elite Meet in Crete
Visit Marcus Pollux in your capital city to receive this quest.

To my loyal subjects: \n \nI am Ashoka the Great, and my empire welcomes those from all lands. While I eagerly anticipate meeting you all in person, please allow this edict to serve as a welcome. As your king, you are my children. I consider it my duty to promote the virtue of all my children. And hard work is the root of virtue. Therefore, as reward for your hard work and for your virtue in a symbol of my love for you as your king, I offer you this priceless treasure, Ashoka’s Golden Gorget. I lay before you a list of challenging tasks, but those who work hard shall be rewarded.
You need to be level 40 to access this quest.

It is good to see you. Rome has been overrun by Celtic Barbarians. \n \nOne day, we will gather our forces and strike back! But before then, let's make sure the surviving locals don't die to the invaders. Get out there and save our people!

Capua connects Rome to all of southern Italy with its central location along the Appian Way. Capua's beauty and wealth earn it the distinction as second in Italy only to Rome. Pompey the Great currently resides in Capua to keep one eye on the menacing Volsci and another eye on Rome.
The Roman Army Camp is strategically positioned deep in northern Italy to give Mark Antony and his Roman legions leverage against both the greedy Etruscans and the invading Celts.
Combat units are trained at military buildings like the Castellum.

These guys think they're too good to help Villagers with gathering resources. But at least they're pretty good at building stuff. I guess it's better than nothing. They also make Millariums, so there's that.
You have a special unit at your command on this quest, the Engineer.
Engineers are trained at the Town Center upon reaching Age II.
They cannot gather resources, but construct and repair buildings much faster than Villagers.
They also construct Millariums, which increase the movement speed of nearby Military Units.

So this quest is a little different compared to most others you've played. You actually start in the enemy base, but they don't want to attack you... yet.

You have a Celtic ally to the south east that can help you.

Favorably located along the Silk Road between impassable mountains and lush jungles, the Indians connect the wonders of the Greeks and Egyptians with the advancements of the Chinese.
 
The Indians endure through the Ages positioned at the forefront of technology.
 
Amass Food with abundant Plantations or train various elephants including the massive Juggernaut at the Mahout Camp.
 
Devote offerings at the Shrine to spawn helpful monkeys.
 
React to any situation by researching specialized Choose One Technologies.
 
Advance through the Ages and control the world with the Indians!

----------
- Egyptian Elephant Archer: Now costs 4 Population baseline. Hitpoints reduced to 560, from 700. DPS reduced to 40, from 50. Movement Speed increased to 6.5, from 6. Training Time reduced to 22 seconds, from 25. Food cost changed to Wood. (225f/150g -> 225w/150g)
- Egyptian Elephant Archer Champion: Now grants +25% Health, +25% Damage and 10% Movement Speed. No longer grants -1 Population.

----------
- All Champion Mode Quests: 
	- Adjusted the Treasure Guardians' stats so they don't have as much Health and Damage as Legendary quests.
	- Added Sparta Point rewards to all quests: 
		- Five-star quests: 40 Sparta Points
		- Four-star quests: 35 Sparta Points
		- Three-star quests: 30 Sparta Points
		- Two-star quests: 25 Sparta Points
		- One-star quests: 20 Sparta Points

- Legendary: Visiting Calydon: Delayed the initial enemy attacks.
- Legendary: Visiting Therme: Made some adjustments to the quest map to make it more accessible to Ships. Made adjustments to the enemy sea patrols
- Legendary: Visiting Aegion: Made minor adjustments.
- Legendary: First Blood (and its other variants): Made some difficulty adjustments.
- Legendary: Turn the Page (and its other variants): Priests are no longer part of the optional objective restrictions.
- Legendary: It Takes A Pillage (and its other variants): Priests are no longer part of the optional objective restrictions.
- Elite: The Fools on the Hill: Made some difficulty adjustments.
